turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Youre wrong about my being there, though. Carlos borrowed my car that day, his had broken down...  Leon saw it, like you, assumed I was there, thought hed wait to ask for a lift. But Carlos turned up, with the tape you found...  Leon got his lift, and accidentally picked up the tape with his photo equipment when he got out. He watched it, confronted Carlos, threatened to tell the police about the hotel... I dont know how he knew about the hotel. Perhaps Carlos talked too much... My husband did not tell me... You more or less guessed the rest...  I didnt know any of this before you left for Los Angeles.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You dont say.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: That my brother, my husband and your Mr Friedman were linked, that much I had guessed. But that my husband had killed Leon? No.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why did you send me after Friedman? To atone for your sins?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I didnt know my husband and Friedman knew each other. I just...  Do you think we spoke about it? Ive known for five years. Hes known Ive known for five years... But not once have we spoken about it. There are things one just doesnt speak about...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: One just doesnt... Tell me, what does one speak about, huh?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Think what you like. But dont presume to understand.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I dont.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is there anything to understand?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Why do I feel I neednt answer that?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Rich. Young. Beautiful. You must at least get a kick out of what he does to his kids.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You bastard...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Five years of it. Surely, youd have divorced him if he disgusted you?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You splendid bastard...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Are there truly no extenuating circumstances?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: ...Were turning in circles.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: And you still havent told me why you sent me after Friedman.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Maybe I wanted to give my husband a fright.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: A fright?... Five years of cowardice led to your brother being murdered and you wanted to give his murderer a fright?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I didnt know who or what had happened to my brother yet, Mr Lombard!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What was the idea? Husband is filled with fear when he learns his child suppliers being tailed?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Something like that?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What happened? Adonis slapped you about a little and you reverted to cowardice?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Here we go again.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where is that?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Simplify and damn.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Dont you believe in simplicity?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Should I?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: We all have to like what we become. Cowards included. We achieve this by complicating things a little. But its never that complicated really.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You seem to know what youre talking about.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Perhaps it came to me while dying in a Californian desert because a woman set upon giving her husband a fright got slapped about a little.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: My husband didnt need to slap me about, Mr Lombard. I volunteered...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: To get me killed...?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I didnt intend it that way... It just happened.  He heard from Laurence that youd been back.  That wed argued. He asked why and it just happened; I told him everything... I couldnt help it. Wanted to see him scared. I had never seen him scared before, you see...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Well, I hope you enjoyed yourself.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Perhaps I did... Until fear turned into panic. Thats when he hit me, and told me hed killed my brother... You dont know what youve done, he said.  Were in deep trouble, he said. We, he said. We.  Wed both be killed if Friedman ever found out you were working for us, he said. We had to stop you and Friedman meeting...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You know something? Ive just seen so much ugliness I dont think Id mind four walls and dinner served every night at a regular time.  Id hoped to have a private word with Adonis, but if thats the way you want it.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: What are you doing? You cant. I...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Do you think the boy you saved might identify your husband as his purchaser, Deborah? And then, your brothers not buried yet. As I said earlier, an autopsy will...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: He... He is dead!  MY HUSBAND IS DEAD!  Call my parents. Theyll tell you. Call them!

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: Do you think wed let him get away with the murder of my brother?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: We? You and your parents killed your husband?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: No. Not us...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: They found his body yesterday. In the pool at our house in Sao Paulo. He drowned. Drank too much, went for a swim and drowned.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Your flunkey said he was expected back tonight.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: The staff dont know yet...  I called my parents, told them everything...  I just couldnt take any more...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Get to the point, will you...

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: My parents flew back from Israel... Told him they would get him killed unless he flew back to Brazil immediately and agreed to a divorce. He flew back to Brazil...  And his drowning was arranged...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: So you did talk about it, huh?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: On... Once...  Once... What are we... you going to do?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What do you suggest?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I dont know. Everyones dead...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Your parents arranged the visit to my office?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why the hell couldnt you divorce the man?

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: You wouldnt understand.

turns.speaker: DEBORAH
turns.text: I... We have to bury Leon tommorrow...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The dead can wait.

turns.speaker: DIRECTORY ENQUIRIES OPERATOR
turns.text: Directory enquiries. Can I help you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yes. Im trying to reach a friend but I cant get through. The number is 01766 770 471.

turns.speaker: DIRECTORY ENQUIRIES OPERATOR
turns.text: 01766 770 471. Let me check it for you, sir.

turns.speaker: DIRECTORY ENQUIRIES OPERATOR
turns.text: Theres nothing wrong with the line, sir. Are you sure you have the right number? 770 471 is the number of a call box.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: A call box? Thats odd. Where exactly?

turns.speaker: DIRECTORY ENQUIRIES OPERATOR
turns.text: Penrhyndeudraeth, North Wales.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Can you tell me how you spell...

turns.speaker: EFFEMINATE WAITER
turns.text: Good morning, sir. How can I help you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: A coffee and a couple of croissants.

turns.speaker: EFFEMINATE WAITER
turns.text: Crow what?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Croissants.

turns.speaker: EFFEMINATE WAITER
turns.text: Im sorry, sir. Could you try that again?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Croissants. Like that...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The word for those things is croissants.

turns.speaker: EFFEMINATE WAITER
turns.text: Not in America, sir. You must be from Europe.  So, black coffee and a couple of crescents.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: May I ask where youre from, Mr Lamont?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Europe...  France. Im French but I live in London...  ... England.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Youre a long way from home...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You wouldnt have a cigarette, would you?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I dont smoke. If you could get to the point...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Youre sure you wont sit down, Miss Stewart?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Im fine standing, thank you.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Is this some kind of sick stunt? Let me guess.  You want money, right?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: A small loan would be welcome. More urgently, I need access to a telephone and an address where things can be sent to me.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I cant believe this...  Whats coming now, eh? If I dont pay all Hells gonna break loose, is that it?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Well, Id sooner mug an old lady...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: You...  Jesus Christ!

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Okay. The woman just cant walk away...  I want straight answers. No hesitation or I walk for sure. Why cant you go to your Embassy?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: French people need a visa to enter this country. That takes time and I didnt have any. I used a British passport. My names not Lamont but Lombard. Xavier Lombard.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Where were you staying before the attempt on your life and why cant you go back there?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The Mondrian, room 504. I was checked out in my absence.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: By your Austrian?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: You dont know why hes come to Los Angeles?  The man you say he killed? Who was he? A colleague of his?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: No. A poor little rich boy who thought hed save a few kids from their retailer. He disappeared on his second shopping expedition.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Have you never heard of collect calls, Mr...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Lombard...  It will take a few days for the things I need to get here. Meanwhile Id sooner not draw police attention walking the streets like a hungry dog...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: There are over 4 million people in this city - why me?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I thought youd never ask... As I was having my coffee and crescents at the Mondrian the other morning I spotted your photograph in the Los Angeles Times... Theres a tough lady, I thought. Just the kind who might help me...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: You know where to look for your Austrian, right?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I know where to look.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: I might come back, I might not. But if I do, it wont be for a couple of hours.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Thereve been 7 international treaties since 1904 aimed at preventing child slavery. But still no worldwide body dedicated to investigating the maltreatment of children used in sexual exploitation. Officially, its just not called for. Sit down. Can I offer you some coffee?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I wouldnt mind. Thank you.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: A recent acquisition. Weve had four break- ins this year alone; files stolen, computers wrecked, faeces smeared on walls. The good guys dismiss us as alarmist do-gooders; the bad guys will risk prison to intimidate and rob us. An easy living indeed, Mr Lombard.  I got through to Moreau and Jane. I left your landlord out of it. Your flats been broken into. Jane wants you to call her back.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Hah... What about Nathalie?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: No answer. You have no passport and your Embassys out. How do you plan to leave the U.S., Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Im sure Ill find a way.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Like youll find a way to stop your Austrian killing you a second time round?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Thank you for the guided tour, but would you mind telling me what were doing here?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: How come youre alive? Child traffickers usually achieve what they set out to do.  What am I really looking at here, huh?  Are you really not just a lousy private eye? Am I really looking at some kind of cunning dispenser of justice in disguise?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Did you call me up here to enjoy yourself, Emily, or to let me use your phone? Because we seem to have a slight problem...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Its give and take time, Mr Lombard. You need help, we need information. You didnt really expect me to put my ass on the line helping a criminal just for the thrill of it, did you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: A criminal?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Did you not enter this country illegally?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Huh... I have no... ... hard evidence...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Come on, Mr Lombard. You tailed your man all the way here from Europe. You told me you knew where to find him, remember? Or didnt I hear you right?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: A little too tight, eh?  ...They were my sons. Only thirteen and already six feet tall. A real lanky boy...  I... Theres some cold chicken salad in the fridge if youre hungry.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Thank you. But I think Ill go to bed. Its been a long day.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Right... Well, Ill get your money first thing in the morning, okay?  Okay. Goodnight then.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yeah. Goodnight, Emily.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Dont fall asleep with your hair wet.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: What am I to do with the packages if...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Burn the passport and keep the money. Think of it as a donation to the cause...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Get a pen and dont ask any questions.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Oh. What... Yeah. Okay.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Route 395. Past Edwards Air Force base and about half a mile before a place called the Red Mountain Motel. Theres a dirt track with a Closed to the public sign. It leads to some kind of ranch in the middle of nowhere. If you havent heard from me by morning send the cavalry, okay? But not before, you hear?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Have you found your man? Is that where he is?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I think so. And if it comes to it, tell the cops anything you think will make them move. Whatever you came up with couldnt come close to how bad it is. Bye now.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Look, you dont tell me about some Godforsaken place where stuff so bad even I couldnt imagine it goes down and expect me to go quietly to sleep! What happened? Whos the guy? The Austrian?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Whos the guy? Whos the guy! Nom de Dieu!  Had the guy got a closer look at you or your number plate Id have had to kill him.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What...  Some kind of organ factory... Pregnant girls doped up. Babies. Theres a lot of people back there. Theyre holding a seminar. Traffickings the past, breeding the future...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Friedmans dead... They killed him...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: So who... Whos the man? Where is he?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Some Italian I picked up back there. Hes in the boot of the Mustang.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Italian? The Mafia...?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Who knows. Who cares...  You wanted slime. You got slime.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: No one saw me but the Italian and a dog. I blew up their generator. They thought it was an accident but by now they must have realised one of their party is missing. It might make them feel insecure enough to decide to pack up...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Were both thinking the same thing, right?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Do you know a friendly cop?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Call from the motel and tell him if he moves fast enough there might be something left of a body dissolving in acid.  Can I have the keys to your house?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: That-that wont do. Thats not the way it goes. You saw it, you tell it, thats the way...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Im finished here and Im tired, Emily. You shouldnt be here. Now dont make it worse.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: A seminar in a baby breeding farm! Bodies in acid! You think Ill get anywhere with that? Jesus! With luck I might raise a laugh. They might even send a patrol car to check the place out. Whatever, itll be too late.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Then find another way.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Look! Either you talk or the creeps are gonna walk. For gods sake. What am I supposed to say? I got this from a French guy from England who broke in there to have a chat with an Austrian child trafficker? Is that it?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Damn it! You cant fucking walk away from this!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Its up to you whether they walk or not.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: ...Im Emily Stewart. The hysterical female who sees evil everywhere since the day her thirteen year-old boy disappeared. The pain in the ass who cries wolf at the drop of a hat. However I go about this thats who I am. Do you get what Im fucking saying, Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What about your friendly cop?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: My ex-husband. My work drove him away. Made his life a misery. He thinks Im obsessed, punishing myself for what happened to our son.  But hes a good guy. Hell listen to you. He wont turn you in if I ask him not to. I can pretty much guarantee that. Okay?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Theyd never let me go. And youd end up in more trouble than you know for helping me.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: You cannot walk away from this. You cannot.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I can... The question is, can you lie to your ex- husband?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Nothing sticks to slime, Emily.  This should cover what you lent me.

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Huh! And they say charitys only rewarded in Heaven... Hallelujah...  Christ...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Whitney Armstrong, my deputy. What Whitneys trying to say is that you might not live to tell the tale next time you meet your Austrian...

turns.speaker: WHITNEY
turns.text: And losing you, wed lose him. And that would be a shame, dont you agree?

turns.speaker: WHITNEY
turns.text: Hi...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: If you have hard evidence about a child trafficker, we want it, Mr Lombard. And we want it before you get yourself killed...

turns.speaker: WHITNEY
turns.text: Most of our information comes out of the mouths of babes, Mr Lombard - confused and frightened victims. Its all too easily discredited, you understand. Now, you might be just what weve been waiting for. Your information could be enough to make em sit up and listen.

turns.speaker: WHITNEY
turns.text: Weve still got the Italian...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Thats right. Wheres the fucking Italian, eh, Mr French hero?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Look at him, Whitney. Come all the way from England to clean up California. Huh!

turns.speaker: WHITNEY
turns.text: Emily...

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: No. Youre looking at a real Musketeer here, Whitney. Brave and rash. Had to dash in there.  Take a prisoner... Might as well have sent them a notice to quit...  Come on, Musketeer! Got anything to say?

turns.speaker: EMILY
turns.text: Shit! Fuck! Whats fucking wrong with people!  Im going to bed. And sweet dreams to you to!

turns.speaker: WHITNEY
turns.text: Shell be alright. Shes tough...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Im calling about the puppies.

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: Have we done business before?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I saw the ad at Georges.  Im passing through town and Im in a hurry.

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: May I have your phone number?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: This is a bad line.

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: What sort of puppy are you looking for?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What sort have you got?

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: Pups. Bitches. From three to twelve months.  Trained and untrained ones. White and brown ones. You understand?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: We also provide 24-hour after-sale service. Were the puppy to fall sick or accidently die, we would unburden you, you understand?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yes... Good, good...

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: So, what are you looking for?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What about an untrained pup, white...

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: How much of a hurry are you in?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Tomorrow?

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: Im afraid the only pups currently available at such notice are brown and trained. But they are all very cheerful and have been thoroughly checked for diseases...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I see. How much?

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: Fifteen for a straight delivery. Twenty with the provision of a safe place. Visitors tend to find the second option more convenient.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: ... Fine. Ill go for the safe place.

turns.speaker: FRIEDMAN
turns.text: Have the money ready by 11am. Well call you.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: On the bed!

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where is the Austrian?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: You... Fuck you!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Youre not playing with little boys now, scumbag. Where is the Austrian?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Jee... Fuck... Youre fucking mad!

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where is the Austrian? Is Friedman the Austrian?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Yes. Friedmans the fuckin Austrian!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where is he?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: I dont know. Hes gone!  Hes gone. I dont fucking know where, I swear... Hes gone. On holiday...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: ...On holiday?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Yeah... This morning. He left this fucking bloody morning... Jesus, man, my knees...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Whos the money man?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Who?  Martin... Hes Martin...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Ever seen him before?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: No... No...  I swear...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Whats this place? A hotel of some kind?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Yeah... The Diplomat.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where are we?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Finsbury Park. Were in Finsbury Park.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where are the kids?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: What kids?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: There were six on offer, you scumbag. Where are the other five?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: I dont know...  This is just a delivery place, man! I swear I dont know where the kids are... I work for Martin, thats all. Martin knows. He works for Friedman. He knows...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: And who does Friedman work for?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: The company. We all work for the company.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What company?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: I dont know. I dont know, man. I dont even know Friedman that well... I...  Man, youve got to get me out of here...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: How many of you scumbags are here?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Just me...  Martins gone back to the Ambassador. Look...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Whats the Ambassador?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Another hotel. Down the road. Martin lives there. He took your money. Hes got a safe...  I need a doctor...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What about the staff?  Theyre in on whats going on, arent they?  How many of them?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: F-five. The Wilsons and their three kids. They run the place. Look, man, Ive got to get to...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What colour is your car?  What colour is your car?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: B-Black...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where is it?

turns.speaker: GIANT
turns.text: Downstairs... At the front... Jesus...

turns.speaker: HYATT OPERATOR
turns.text: Im sorry but Mr Gluck is not answering, sir.  Would you like to leave a message?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Ill call again.

turns.speaker: HYATT OPERATOR
turns.text: The Hyatt. Good afternoon. May I help you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Can I have the reception desk, please.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Does Mr Gluck call for his messages?

turns.speaker: HYATT OPERATOR
turns.text: Absolutely, sir. As a matter of fact he called this morning, sir.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Next time he calls tell Mr Gluck he better be there to take his calls at 9 tonight or at 9 in the morning if he cares about his puppies. Got that?

turns.speaker: HYATT OPERATOR
turns.text: Got it. Puppies.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You sure you passed on my message?

turns.speaker: HYATT OPERATOR
turns.text: I certainly did, sir...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Hello again, neighbour. I didnt intrude, did I?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: How are you, Jane?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Fine. How was the match? Did you loose?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Must be your lucky day then. Ive got your accounts - you dont owe much tax for last year.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes. But my boss reckons youd still be better off as a limited company. For expenses and all that, you know? Itd cost you about £100 but he said itd be worth it.  Of course, youd need a partner to register. But thats a formality. I mean, I could be your partner. I mean, just as a name, right?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Have you heard of a French film called La Collectionoose?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: La what?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: La collectionoose. Its about a young girl in the south of France who seduces a different man every night and then meets one who resists her. Its on TV tonight and as Im in I thought we could perhaps look at your accounts and... The review says its about the conflict between intellect and instinct. And witty. The directors supposed to be famous. Rommel or something. French. You must know him?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Should I?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I dont know. How many famous French film directors can there be?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: That are called Rommel or something, I guess not that many.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: So you havent seen the film, then?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Its Friday night, Jane. What happened to your latest boyfriend?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Oh... We split up.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Well, I hope youre not too heartbroken and...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Oh no. Im all right. He was a jerk, really. Another boy, you know? All I meet is boys. When I think of all the fuss about older men fancying young girls. I mean, is it true?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Ive got work tonight, Jane.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Oh yeah! Better be good and hurry away then! Who knows? We might be being watched! Maybe one of your stupid French companies has got a detective prying into your life - after all, thats what they do to their employees, isnt it? Huh! Hope you enjoy ruining peoples lives. Thanks for the lift!

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Shes pretty... See you, huh?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Bye bye, Jane. And dont be naughty.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I came to feed your fish. I didnt know...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Oui, bonjour, Jean... Oui, très bien, merci. Dites-moi, pourriez-vous me dire si vous avez recommandémes services àquelquun récemment... Vous êtes certain... Non, non...  Je vous remercie...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Hello there. Hows the flat. I cleaned...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Jane, there was an envelope in my desk. The one Id given you and then got back, remember? I cant find it. Do you know where it is?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: No... I told you on the phone. Whoever broke in messed-up all your papers. I put everything back where I thought it ought to be.  Maybe its there with...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Its not.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Well, Im sorry. I...  This is my nephew... And my brother, Tim. Ive got the week off and hes come to stay.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Piss off!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Thanks for cleaning my flat and sending my money, all right?... Come on, I need you. Its important.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Just ask if they can recall recommending my services to anyone in the recent past. Say youre my secretary, all right?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Your secretary, huh!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Id appreciate it if you could do this for me. If you cant, dont worry about it. Ill call in about an hour anyway. Sorry but Im in a hurry.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: What are you up to, eh, Savieer? I mean, not this but... Money, passports, a gun in a microwave? Who are you, eh? Who are you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Hello, Jane. Its me.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Really? And how are you, eh?  Someone called Pierre Dreyer said that a month ago he had dinner with a Brazilian friend of...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Carlos De Moraes?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Yes. How did...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Thank you, Jane.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Good afternoon, Mrs...?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Spitz. We spoke on the telephone.  My husband...  My daughter, Deborah, whose house this is.  My son-in-law, Carlos...  The gentleman is a business partner of his.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: May I...?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: May I ask if you are Jewish, Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Lombard, this is not a Jewish name, is it?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I hope its not too significant.

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: What if it is?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Well, I would have to point out that we could have dealt with that question when you called this morning, Mrs Spitz. I wouldnt like to think Id kept you waiting for nothing.

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Whatever, you come recommended. We...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Recommended?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Must I speak to you in French?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Didnt you say I came recommended?  Thats what I thought. May I know by whom?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: You may not. And besides, it is irrelevant.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Okay. Recommended...

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Good. Now, as I trust you may have guessed, we are looking for someone to work for us. Someone whose discretion can be relied upon. Someone who while in our employ would give us full commitment. Do you think you could be that person, Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Look Mrs Spitz... I dont know to whom Im indebted for the recommendation but... Im not in the business of making oaths of allegiance or giving myself character references. What I do is listen to what the people who care to call me have to say and judge whether or not I can be of help. I hope you can appreciate that, Mrs Spitz.

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: What I can appreciate is insolence, Mr Lombard!

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I take it your son is called Leon?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Leonard. What my daughter is on about, Mr Lombard, is that Leonard is somewhat of a Bohemian. You might as well know that...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What do you think has happened to your son, Mrs Spitz?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: You wouldnt be here if I knew, Mr Lombard. What I do know is that he has not been at work for three weeks. That enquiries to the police and London hospitals have borne no results. And that a check with his bank revealed he has not used his account for four weeks now.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: How did you do that, Mrs Spitz?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Do what, Mr Lombard?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Check with your sons bank. Banks dont usually give out information about their customers.

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: I said earlier that my husband and I are supporting Leonard in his photography, Mr Lombard. By this I mean that since his return from America I have been depositing for him a monthly allowance in an account we jointly hold. So as you see, I did not have to break the law to find out if he used the account.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I didnt mean to imply you did, Mrs Spitz.

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Then you should not have sought an explanation.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I presume you checked your sons apartment...

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Yesterday. It all looked normal.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Did you look for his passport, driving licence?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Leonard does not hold a driving licence. As for his passport, I do not know where he keeps it.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: So he could have decided to go on a trip...

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: He could indeed, Mr Lombard. But had he done so I think he would have let us know about it.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Then why arent you asking the police to look for your son, Mrs Spitz?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I take it your son is not married, Mrs Spitz?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: No. And before you ask, no, hes not gay! He has had girlfriends, but nothing serious...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Any friends?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: The proprietor of his workplace is the only friend of his we know about.  His address is in this envelope with Leonards address, keys and other things you might need.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Im sure... As far as you know, when and where was your son last seen?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: When... Im told he came here...

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: The £1,000 is on account.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: My rates...

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: We are aware of your rates, Mr Lombard. We will pay you double your rates plus expenses. In return, need I say it again, we expect discretion and undivided attention.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Why do you think your son chose not to come to you for funds for his photography, Mrs Spitz?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Ha... No, Mr Lombard. His monthly allowance is all he is to expect from us. He knows it and we feel the amount is more than adequate.

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: My husband and I will be leaving tomorrow for a short stay in Israel. Deborah will be here if you need anything before our return.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Fine. One more thing, Mrs and Mr Spitz; may I ask what is or was your occupation?

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: £10,000 a year to the girl for as long as she looks after the boy?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Plus a trust fund to provide for the boys education.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Look at it this way. He might achieve everything your son never did.

turns.speaker: MRS SPITZ
turns.text: Jah...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What happens now?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: We conclude our transaction.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: The rooms yours for 24 hours. Its sound- proofed, stocked up with food, drink and other things you might find useful. You can do anything you like.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Anything at all?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Anything at all. I presume you wont want to take the boy with you when youre finished?  Theres a £500 fee for disposal. The boy is yours, you understand?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Vous êtes Français?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Does it matter?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Problems?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is my money in there?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Uh-huh. You couldve waited for me inside.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Lets go.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I dont know what your problem is, but...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Right now your big friend at the Diplomat is bleeding fast, Martin. He might still possibly survive if attended to soon. And he did cooperate.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Am I supposed to know him?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Six weeks ago. He bought a boy of yours.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Clients come and go.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: This one came back and was never seen again. I understand Friedman looked after him.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Huh, I doubt it...  Friedman only deals directly with select customers. I handle the rabble...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Where is Friedman?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Look, I dont think youre fully aware of what youre playing with here, Mister. Whoever put you up to this either pays too well or misinformed you. Why dont you just tell me what it is you want so we can do business in a civilized manner, eh?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Friedman lives with you at the Ambassador?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: No. In Hampstead... Why?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Dont jump any red lights.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: This car needs petrol.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Shut up and drive!

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Youre out of your mind. Whats the idea?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Maybe the thought of people like you going on holiday bothers me. Come on, lets go...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is it real?  You people are sick.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Huh. Id have thought a tough guy like you would know better. The sick ones are out there, friend. They make up the clientèle. Get rid of them and were out of business.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Only feeding the disease, eh, Martin?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Money talks, bullshit walks, whether you like it or not.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Maybe I dont.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Maybe you should. Think about it. Those who can afford our goods do their thing without upsetting anyone. Those who cant do it to kids from the streets or their own family and it makes upsetting headlines.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Im overcome by your public-spiritedness.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Boys like the one you met today are surplus. Commodities worth a handful of notes in whatever arsehole of the world they happen to be born into. We improve some lives buying them where theyre not wanted, improve still more selling them where they are. Is that too hard for you?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You know what, Martin? I ought to tie you down with your old arse up in the air and advertise the hole in the middle of it to the world. Free. And hope you never die.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Huh... Im sure thered be lots of takers.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Could someone have hurt you that bad?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is this Friedman?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Who are you? Who are you working for, huh?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is this Friedman, Martin?  Come on, scumbag. Youve reached your sell- by date. Tell me if this is Friedman, where he is in Los Angeles and what name hes using?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Youre making a mistake, tough guy. Whoever he is, your guys not one of Friedmans...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: You seem very sure about that.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I told you... The rabble, its me...  Huh... Its sad.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What is?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Dying without ever reaching the top...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Trying to say something, Martin?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Hyatt... Friedmans... at the Hyatt...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The Hyatt...? Whats that?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Ho-hotel... Los Angeles... He...

turns.speaker: MANS VOICE
turns.text: Its about the puppy. You got the money?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MANS VOICE
turns.text: At what time will you be available?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Three oclock.

turns.speaker: MANS VOICE
turns.text: Le Mercury. Newman street. Ask for Peter.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: MANS VOICE
turns.text: This is the hotel supervisor, Mr Lamont. Im terribly sorry to disturb you but theres been a mix-up with our bookings which you might be able to help us resolve.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: MANS VOICE
turns.text: We need a double-room and as I understand youre here alone wed be much obliged if youd agree to move to a single room...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Five to three. Youre early.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Should I come back in five minutes?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I gather weve done business with a friend of yours?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Have you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: The person who put us in touch seems to think so.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: I dont recollect mentioning a friend.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Your lady friend did.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: The ladys not a friend. Shes a whore.  Someone at a special screening I attended mentioned certain goods could be got from an Austrian here in London. And not just movies.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And while visiting our fair city you...  An Austrian?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: An Austrian.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: An Austrian... Not much to go on, is it?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Questions can amount to revelations. Now, Id hate to think I was made to come here carrying a substantial amount of money in order to be subjected to a cross- examination. Mr Friedman led me to believe we had a deal. Do we?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Will you be alone?  The merchandise. Is it just you or...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Ill be alone.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You must agree to be blindfolded...  Just for the journey. It might appear unseemly - youre the paying customer - but ordinarily clients come with some kind of endorsement.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Evening. Table for one?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: No. Thank you. Could you tell me if Leon Spitz is here, please?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Leon? No. Im afraid he left.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Left? When? I just come from his place and there was no one there. A neighbour of his...

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: No. I meant he left as in no longer works here.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Oh. This is... Wed arranged to meet tonight and Im due to return to Paris tomorrow...

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Im sorry...

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Yes. You wouldnt know where I could reach him? We had to discuss an exhibition of his photographs at my Paris gallery, you see? I really need to see him before I leave.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: This is private property. The public footpath is back to the left of the bridge.

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: How are you, Rhian?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Its wet. Will this do?

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Wheres your wallet? Have you got a wallet?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: Is this some kind of mugging? Because...

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Shut up! Wheres your wallet?

turns.speaker: LOMBARD
turns.text: In my jacket. Left inside pocket.

turns.speaker: RHIAN
turns.text: Reach for it and throw it to me. And... My fingers on the trigger, you hear!
